variant.question: A modern aircraft has three Air Data Inertial Reference Units (ADIRUs). Each ADIRU combines an IRU with _____, which sends barometric altitude and TAS information to the IRU.

options.text: an Air Data Computer.
an Electronic Attitude Direction Indicator.
a Flight Management Computer.
an Attitude and Heading Reference System.

variant.question: If the Air Data Computer fails, what information is lost to the flight crew?

options.text: Wind speed and direction.
Drift angle.
Groundspeed.
Time at next waypoint.

variant.question: The Mach number is subject to position error. This error varies with:

options.text: Mach number and angle of attack.
TAS only.
OAT only.
TAS and OAT.

variant.question: The ADC (Air Data Computer) supplies data to the following: - EFIS symbol generator - Transponder - Auto Flight System The combination that regroups all of the correct statements is:
With constant weight and configuration, an aircraft always takes off at the same

options.text: equivalent airspeed.
ground speed.
indicated airspeed.
true airspeed.

variant.question:
An air data computer (ADC):
1) supplies the ground speed and the drift angle.
2) determines the total temperature and the true altitude.
3) receives the static pressure and the total pressure.
4) supplies the TAS to the computer of the INS.
5) determines the Mach number, the outside (static) air temperature.
The combination that regroups all of the correct statements is:
At constant weight, regardless of altitude, an aircraft always lifts off at a constant

options.text: EAS
CAS
ground speed
TAS

variant.question: In An Air Data Computer (ADC), aeroplane altitude is calculated from:

options.text: measurement of barometric pressure from a static source on the fuselage.
measurement of outside air temperature (OAT).
the difference between absolute and dynamic pressure at the fuselage.
measurement of elapsed time for a radio signal transmitted to the ground surface and back.

variant.question: The error in a direction indicator caused by the convergence of the meridians in northerly and southerly latitudes is called:

options.text: transport error.
turning error.
drift error.
mechanical error.

variant.question: When, in flight, the needle of a needle-and-ball indicator is on the left and the ball on the right, the aircraft is

options.text: turning left with not enough bank.
turning left with too much bank.
turning right with too much bank.
turning right with not enough bank.

variant.question: The alignment time, at mid-latitudes, for an Inertial Reference System using laser ring gyros is approximately

options.text: 10 min.
5 min.
2 min.
20 min.

variant.question: The characteristics of the Earth which are being used during the alignment of an INS platform are:

options.text: Earth rotation and gravity.
Earth rotation and longitude.
longitude and gravity.
Earth magnetic field and earth rotation.

variant.question: How long will the ADIRU alignment approximately take at around 60º latitude?

options.text: 10 minutes.
No time because an ADIRU does NOT require alignment.
5 minutes.
20 minutes.

variant.question: The alignment of a gyro stabilised inertial platform consists in positioning the platform relative to:

options.text: the vertical axis and true north.
the roll axis only.
the pitch axis only.
the pitch and roll axes.

variant.question: The alignment of a gyro stabilised inertial platform consists in positioning the platform relative to:

options.text: the vertical axis and true north.
the roll axis only.
the pitch axis only.
the pitch and roll axis.

variant.question: The alignment of a gyro stabilized inertial platform consists in positioning the platform relative to:

options.text: the vertical axis and true north.
the pitch and roll axis.
the roll axis only.
the pitch axis only.

variant.question: In a stabilised platform inertial system, the accelerations are measured in an axis co-ordinate system which is: (NB: aircraft`s body axis co-ordinate system = pitch, roll and yaw axis)

options.text: free from the aircraft`s body axis co-ordinate system.
merged with only two axes of the aircraft`s body axis co-ordinate system: the roll and the pitch axis.
fixed in absolute space.
merged with the aircraft`s body axis co-ordinate system.

variant.question:
A pilot accidentally turning OFF the INS in flight, and then turns it back ON a few moments later
Following this incident

options.text: it can only be used for attitude reference.
the INS is usable in NAV mode after a position update.
everything returns to normal and is usable.
no useful information can be obtained from the INS.

variant.question: The full alignment of a stabilised platform inertial system can be carried out:

options.text: on the ground only and when the aircraft is at a full stop.
at any time as long as an accurate position is computed by the FMS.
during any phase of flight.
on the ground or when in straight and level flight.

variant.question: The full alignment of a stabilised platform inertial system can be carried out:

options.text: on the ground only and when the aircraft is at a full stop.
on the ground or when in straight and levelled flight.
during any phase of flight.
at any time as long as an accurate position is computed by the FMS.

variant.question: When an INS loses its alignment reference during flight, the..

options.text: NAV mode is lost until the next alignment is carried out on the ground.
pilot must select STBY on the mode selector unit and wait for about 3 minutes before switching to the ALIGN mode.
pilot must select ALIGN on the mode selector unit and wait for about 10 minutes.
INS loses all functionality and should be switched off to save electrical power.

variant.question: When and where are IRS positions updated?

options.text: Only on the ground during the alignment procedure.
When the VHF Nav Radios are selected to AUTO.
When the FMS is in IRS ONLY NAV operation.
During all phases of flight.

variant.question:
Considering a stabilised platform inertial system, this platform:
1.  can be servo-controlled in azimuth
2.  is kept levelled during alignment phase only
3.  is always kept levelled
The combination that regroups all of the correct statements is:
When the rotary knob on the INS control panel is set to "NAV" mode, it is:

options.text: the normal operating mode allowing use of all the functions of the system.
the navigation mode allowing use of all the functions of the system except heading.
the alignment function in flight.
the navigation mode allowing use of all the functions of the system except attitude.

variant.question: The strap-down IRS...

options.text: is located close to the aircraft CG, and uses laser gyros to calculate angular movements.
consists of gyros and accelerometers. The gyros keep the platform level and the accelerometers calculate acceleration.
is located away from the aircraft CG and uses laser gyros to calculate accelerations.
is most reliable with a low frequency laser beam.

variant.question: An IRS is aligned in order to

options.text: calculate the computed trihedron with respect to the Earth.
establish true and Magnetic North.
establish position relative to True North and Magnetic North.
establish Magnetic North.

variant.question:
Concerning an IRS:

1 – the aircraft may be moved during the alignment   
2 – the aircraft must not be moved during alignment   
3 – exceptionally, the alignment can be done in flight.
The combination that regroups all of the correct statements is:
What is the average position error of a stabilised-platform Inertial Navigation System (INS)?

options.text: 1.5 NM/hour or more.
3.0 NM/hour or more.
0.5 NM/hour or less.
1 NM/hour or less.

variant.question: The position error of a stand alone inertial system, is approximately:

options.text: 0.5 to 2 NM per hour.
8 to 10 NM per hour.
0.01 to 0.2 NM per hour.
6 to 8 NM per hour.

variant.question: In order to align an inertial reference system (IRS), it is required to insert the local geographical coordinates. This enables the IRS to:

options.text: compare the latitude it finds with that entered by the operator.
compare the longitude it finds with that entered by the operator.
find True North.
initialize the FMS flight plan.

variant.question: Which one of the following can lead to loss of alignment in an INS?

options.text: Entering the wrong longitude before initial alignment.
Flying through or in the vicinity of thunderstorms.
Sudden aircraft attitude changes due to turbulence or similar disturbances.
Entering the wrong latitude before initial alignment.

variant.question: How does an IRS work?

options.text: The IRS is located close to the aircraft C/G and it uses laser gyros to calculate angular rotations.
It consists of gyros and accelerometers. The gyros keep the platform level and the accelerometers calculate acceleration.
The IRS is most reliable using lower frequency laser beams.
The IRS is located a bit away from the aircraft C/G and it uses laser gyros to calculate accelerations.

variant.question: How does an IRS work?

options.text: An IRS is located close to the aircrafts' centre of gravity and it uses laser gyros to calculate accelerations.
An IRS is located a bit away from the aircrafts' centre of gravity and it uses laser gyros to calculate accelerations.
An IRS is most reliable with low frequencies of the laser beam.
An IRS consists of gyros and accelerometers. The gyros keep the platform level and the accelerometers calculate accelerations.

variant.question: Which of the following statements concerning the initial position indicated on the Inertial Reference System (IRS) display is correct?

options.text: It is not updated once the IRS mode is set to NAV.
The positions from the two IRSs are compared to obtain a best position which is displayed on the IRS.
It is constantly updated from information obtained by the FMC.
It is updated when go-around is selected on take-off.

variant.question:
The alignment phase of an IRS consists of:
1. searching for the local vertical
2. searching for the true North
3. searching for the latitude
4. searching for the longitude
5. comparison between the computed longitude and the one entered by the pilot
6. comparison between the computed latitude and the one entered by the pilot
The combination that regroups all of the correct statements is:
The full alignment of an IRS will be successful if the following data is inserted by the pilot:

options.text: aircraft position (latitude and longitude).
aircraft magnetic heading.
airport elevation.
aircraft true heading.

variant.question: Where is the majority of the output data from the INS/IRS presented on?

options.text: CDU
CDI
ADI
ADU

variant.question: How long does it normally take to align an INS/IRS at mid latitudes?

options.text: About 20 minutes
About 10 minutes
Up to 30 minutes
Up to 5 minutes

variant.question: The resultant of the second integration from the North / South accelerometer of an inertial navigation system (INS) in the NAV mode is

options.text: distance North / South.
distance East / West.
velocity North / South.
velocity East / West.

variant.question: The position error of a stand alone inertial system is:

options.text: small a few minutes after initialisation and increases along the flight.
constant along the flight with an accuracy depending on the accuracy of the accelerometers.
large a few minutes after initialisation and reduces along the flight.
small and constant along the flight.

variant.question:
(Refer to the question annex).
In flight, the IRS detects a critical fault with excessive position error. Regarding the mode selector switch, the crew should select...

options.text: ATT, to retain attitude information.
OFF, since the system is unreliable.
NAV, and monitor the position error.
OFF then NAV, to realign the system.

variant.question:
The mode selector of an inertial navigation unit (INS) comprises the OFF - STBY - ALIGN - NAV - ATT positions:
1) on "STBY" the unit aligns on the local geographic trihedron.
2) the "ATT" position is used in automatic landing (mode LAND).
3) on "NAV" the coordinates of the present position are entered.
4) on "ALIGN" the unit aligns on the local geographic trihedron.
5) on "ALIGN" current position is updated upon the aircraft alignment on the runway.
The combination regrouping all the correct statements is:
Before the INS alignment the pilot accidentally provides the system with an INCORRECT value of latitude. What is the consequence of this action?

options.text: The system will gradually lose its alignment, as the calculated drift due to Earth rotation will be wrong.
The system will start up in ATT REF mode, providing attitude data, but NOT navigation data.
Nothing. The system will compensate for such errors, but the initial alignment process will take longer.
The system will only function correctly when flying east-west, NOT north-south.

variant.question: How does the IRS compare to the INS?

options.text: The IRS is a later version of the INS, fitted with Ring laser gyros.
The IRS is simply a derivative of the INS, functioning exactly in the same way.
Both systems use the RLG system, but only one of them is strap-down.
The INS is the oldest system of them two, that functions using the RLG system.

variant.question: How can an INS/IRS be realigned in flight if alignment is lost for some reason?

options.text: It can NOT the aircraft must be stationary on the ground for alignment to be performed.
By setting the INS mode selector to "ALIGN" and waiting for the required time.
By setting the INS mode selector to "GPS" and realigning the INSARS through the GPS.
By setting the INS mode selector to "ALIGN" and then flying straight and level with NO airspeed variations for at least 10 minutes.

variant.question: In an Inertial Navigation System (INS), Ground Speed (GS) is calculated:

options.text: by integrating measured acceleration.
from TAS and W/V from Air Data Computer (ADC).
from TAS and W/V from RNAV data.
by integrating gyro precession in N/S and E/W directions respectively.

variant.question: The full alignment of the stable platform of an Inertial Navigation System:

options.text: is only possible on the ground when the aircraft is at a complete stop.
may be carried out on the ground or when in straight and level flight.
may be carried out at any time so long as an accurate position is inserted into the system.
may be carried out during any phase of flight.

variant.question: The alignment phase of a gyro stabilised platform consists of:

options.text: levelling the platform and determining its orientation.
aligning the platform axes with the aircraft axes (pitch, roll, yaw).
aligning the platform axes with the aircraft roll axis only.
aligning the platform axes with the aircraft pitch axis only.

variant.question: The alignment phase of a gyro stabilised platform consists of:

options.text: levelling the platform and determining its orientation.
aligning the platform axes with the aircraft axis (pitch, roll, yaw).
aligning the platform axes with the aircraft roll axis only.
aligning the platform axes with the aircraft pitch axis only.

variant.question: How much time does an ADIRU need for alignment at 60N°?

options.text: 10 minutes.
5 minutes.
It doesn’t require alignment.
20 minutes.

variant.question: The alignment of an inertial system can be sucessfully performed

options.text: when the aircraft is stationary.
in all phases of flight outside areas of turbulence.
in all phases of flight.
when the aircraft is taxiing.

variant.question: When is the last point at which an INS or IRS may be selected to NAV mode?

options.text: Immediately prior to hover taxi
After passengers and freight are aboard
At the holding point
On operation of the TOGA switch after hover taxi to take –off

variant.question: During the initial alignment of an inertial navigation system (INS) the equipment

options.text: Will not accept a 10° error in initial latitude but will accept a 10° error in initial longitude
Will not accept a 10° error in initial latitude or initial longitude
Will accept a 10° error in initial latitude and initial longitude
Will accept a 10° error in initial latitude but will not accept a 10° error in initial longitude

variant.question:
The drift of the azimuth gyro in an inertial unit induces an error
If 't' is the elapsed time, the average total error is

options.text: proportional to t.
proportional to t_ (t squared).
proportional to t/2.
sinusoidal.

variant.question: As a result of the failure of the central air data computer (CADC), the inertial navigation system (INS) will no longer provide information about

options.text: the wind direction and speed.
the time (TIME) at the next waypoint (WPT).
the ground speed.
the drift.

variant.question: Which of the following statements concerning the alignment procedure for Inertial Navigation Systems (INS) / Inertial Reference Systems (IRS) at mid-latitudes is correct?

options.text: INS/IRS can be aligned in either the ALIGN or NAV mode.
INS/IRS can be aligned in either the ALIGN or ATT mode.
INS/IRS can only be aligned in NAV mode.
INS/IRS can only be aligned in the ALIGN mode.

variant.question: After alignment, is it possible to update IRS positions?

options.text: No.
Yes, the process is automatic in flight from the DMEs.
Yes, the pilots can insert updates.
Yes - by operation of the TO/GA switch, the runway threshold co-ordinates are inserted into the IRS.

variant.question: Which of the following are pilot inputs to the IRS?

options.text: Latitude
Magnetic Heading
Magnetic variation
True Heading

variant.question: The platform of an inertial navigation system (INS) is maintained at right angles to the local vertical by applying corrections for the effects of:

options.text: aircraft manoeuvres, Earth rotation, transport wander and Coriolis.
movement in the yawing plane, secondary precession and pendulous oscillation.
gyroscopic inertia, Earth precession and pendulous oscillation.
vertical velocities, Earth precession, centrifugal forces and transport drift.

variant.question: Which of the following statements concerning the loss of alignment by an Inertial Reference System (IRS) in flight is correct?

options.text: The navigation mode, including present position and ground speed outputs, is inoperative for the remainder of the flight.
The mode selector has to be rotated to ATT then back through ALIGN to NAV in order to obtain an in-flight realignment.
The IRS has to be coupled to the remaining serviceable system and a realignment carried out in flight.
It is not usable in any mode and must be shut down for the rest of the flight.

variant.question: If the navigation function of an INS is inoperative and the control rotary switch is set to ATT, the output data of the INS is (are)

options.text: attitude and heading.
attitude and ground speed.
position only.
position and attitude.

variant.question: Where are the outputs from an IRS/INS shown?

options.text: ADIRU
CDU
ADU
CDI

variant.question:
In order to align an IRS, it is required to insert the local geographical co-ordinates. This enables the IRS to:
1. compare the computed latitude with the one entered by the pilot
2. compare the computed longitude with the one entered by the pilot
3. use the longitude
The combination that regroups all of the correct statements is:

The positions of the mode selector of an inertial navigation unit are: OFF – STBY – ALIGN – NAV – ATT:

1 – in "STBY", the unit aligns on the local geographic co-ordinate system2 – the "ATT" position is used during automatic landing (LAND mode)3 – in "NAV" the co-ordinates of the start position can be entered4 – the platform is levelled before azimuth alignment5 – in cruise, the unit can only be used in "NAV" mode.

 In flight, the IRS detects a critical fault with excessive position error. Regarding the mode selector switch, what should the crew select?

options.text: ATT, to retain attitude information.
OFF than NAV, to realign the system.
NAV and monitor the position error.
OFF, since the system is unreliable.

variant.question: If the navigation function of an INS is inoperative, the back up mode if existing, used to operate the INS is:

options.text: the ATT mode which supplies attitude and heading data.
the ATT mode which allows to maintain pitch attitude only.
the GS mode which supplies ground speed and heading data.
the OFF mode which turns off the navigation mode but recovers the heading mode.

variant.question: In an IRS

options.text: accelerometers and platform are both strapped down.
the accelerometers are strapped down but the platform is gyro stabilized.
the platform is strapped down but the accelerometers are gyro stabilized.
accelerometers and platform are both gyro-stabilized.

variant.question: The alignment sequence of an IRS consists of: - Searching for the local vertical - Searching for the true north - Searching for the latitude - Searching for the longitude - Comparison between the computed longitude and the one entered by the pilot - Comparison between the computed latitude and the one entered by the pilot The combination that regroups all of the correct statements is:
What is the main cause of position error over time in a stabilised-platform Inertial Navigation System (INS)?

options.text: Imperfections within gyro bearings and mass imbalances.
Imperfections in the mirrors, their coatings, and misalignment.
Imperfections in the power supply of the INS.
The Earth`s rotation.

variant.question: What happens when the ADIRU is switched to ATT mode?

options.text: The inertial system provides attitude and heading.
Aircraft attitude is monitored to provide flight envelope protection.
The inertial system provides aircraft attitude only.
Position calculation are based on Acceleration, Time and Track.

variant.question: An inertial Navigation System (INS) is:

options.text: a self contained system which operates without signals from the ground.
a radio navigation system.
a system which operates on the Doppler principle.
a hyperbolic navigation system.

variant.question: The time for a normal alignment (not a quick alignment) of a strapdown inertial system is:

options.text: 3 to 10 minutes.
1 to 2 minutes.
15 to 20 minutes.
less than 1 minute.

variant.question: The alignment time, at mid-latitudes, for an Inertial Navigation System using gimbal gyros is approximately

options.text: 15 mins
30 min
45 mins
5 min

variant.question: During initial alignment an inertial navigation system is north aligned by inputs from

options.text: horizontal accelerometers and the east gyro.
the aircraft remote reading compass system.
vertical accelerometers and the north gyro.

variant.question: Considering a strapdown inertial system, the IRU (Inertial Reference Unit) measures

options.text: accelerations and angular rates.
linear accelerations only.
angular accelerations only.
angular rates only.

variant.question: Where and when are the INS positions updated?

options.text: Only on the ground during the alignment procedure.
Updating is normally carried out by the crew when over-flying a known position (VOR station or NDB).
During flight INS positions are automatically updated by the FMC.
INS positions are updated by pressing the Take-off/Go-around button at the start of the take-off roll.

variant.question: On a triple-fit IRS system, present positions on the CDU

options.text: are likely to differ as the information comes from different sources.
will not differ as the information is averaged.
will only differ if one IRS has been decoupled due to a detected malfunction.
will only differ if an initial input error of aircraft position has been made.

variant.question: The resultant of the first integration of the output from the North / South accelerometer of an inertial navigation system (INS) in NAV mode is:

options.text: Velocity along the local meridian.
Ground speed.
Latitude.
Change of latitude.

variant.question: The majority of the output data from the INS/IRS are presented on the...

options.text: CDU.
ADI.
ADU.
CDI.

variant.question: Should an stabilised inertial platform be displaced from the horizontal, it would oscillate with a period of about:

options.text: 84 minutes.
84 seconds.
8 minutes.
4 minutes.

variant.question:
A pilot checks the position error of a stand-alone INS against a known position fix, having completed one hour of flying. The error is approximately 2 NM. This error varies and depends on:1. Gyro drift rate. 
 2. Wind drift.

 4. Initial misalignment 
 5. Computational errors.

options.text: (1) navigation, (2) attitude, (3) CANNOT
(1) navigation, (2) attitude, (3) CAN
(1) attitude, (2) navigation, (3) CANNOT
(1) altitude, (2) navigation, (3) CAN

variant.question: On the INS control panel, the rotary knob can be selected to OFF, NAV or ATT positions. The correct statement is:

options.text: NAV is the normal system setting; the ATT position is the back up position in case of failure of the navigation function.
ATT is the normal system setting.
NAV is the normal system setting; the OFF position is the back up position in case of failure of the navigation function.
ATT is the normal system setting; the NAV position inhibits the attitude data

variant.question: On the INS control panel, the rotary knob can be selected to OFF, NAV or ATT positions. The correct statement is:

options.text: NAV is the normal system setting; the ATT position is the back up position in case of failure of the navigation function.
ATT is the normal system setting; the NAV position inhibits the attitude data.
ATT is the normal system setting.
NAV is the normal system setting; the OFF position is the back up position in case of failure of the navigation function.

variant.question: The parameters that are sensed and used by an IRS for a full successful alignment are:

options.text: earth rotation and gravity.
earth rotation and longitude.
earth magnetic field and earth rotation.

variant.question: What is the average position error of the Inertial Navigation System?

options.text: 1.5 NM per hour or more
1 NM per hour or less
3.0 NM per hour or more
0.5 NM per hour or less

variant.question:

- XTK on INS 1 = 0
- XTK on INS 2 = 8L
From this information it can be deduced that:

only inertial navigation system No. 2 is drifting.
only inertial navigation system No. 1 is drifting.
the autopilot is unserviceable in NAV mode.

OFF - STBY - ATT - NAV.

variant.question:
In a stabilised-platform inertial system, the platfom is
1) Azimuth-controlled to True North.

options.text: 1 and 4
1 and 3
2 and 3

variant.question: After alignment of the stable platform of the Inertial Navigation System, the output data from the INS computer to the platform is:

variant.question: The position error of a stand alone inertial system:

increases up to 2 NM due to the drift error of the gyroscopes, then stabilises.
remains constant.

options.text: closed by the autopilot at the servomotor/controller
closed by the autopilot at the control column

according to an interception versus radio deviation law.

options.text: vertical bar and the horizontal bar on the ADI.

the refuelling process on the ground is stopped before the required amount of fuel is on board.

When less than 25% remains

a combined weather radar, collision avoidance, and terrain indicator
an integrated DME and Horizontal Situation Indicator
an alphabetical performance and navigation database

variant.question: IRS is a self-contained system because

options.text: the system calculates the position of the aircraft without reference to externally generated (man-made) signals.
the system has a battery back-up which guarantees the well-functioning of the system in case of power-failure.
the system has the ability to calculate the aircraft’s radio position without any reference to either man &made or natural information
the system has the ability to calculate the aircraft’s position with an accuracy comparable to the GPS& position

variant.question: IRS is a self-contained system because

options.text: the system calculates the position of the aircraft without reference to externally generated (man-made) signals.
the system has a battery back-up which guarantees the well-functioning of the system in case of power-failure.
the system has the ability to calculate the aircraft’s radio position without any reference to either man-made or natural information
the system has the ability to calculate the aircraft’s position with an accuracy comparable to the GPS position

variant.question: A new data base should be downloaded to the Flight Management System (FMS) on a cycle of every:

options.text: 28 days.
14 days.
90 days.
30 days.

variant.question: The pilot receives instructions from ATC to alter the route during a scheduled flight. What action is required for the IRS?

options.text: Enter the new waypoints into the MCDU of the FMS.
The pilot will need to revert to manual navigation. The aircraft must be stationary to update waypoints in the IRS.
Modern aircraft have GPS, so the pilot does not need to update waypoints in the IRS.
Enter the new waypoints into the control unit of each IRS, ensuring the system in use is updated first.

variant.question: When EGPWS terrain is displayed, if the computed aircraft position becomes less accurate:

options.text: the terrain display will diverge from the real terrain environment around the aircraft position.
the EGPWS will perform a correction of position thus the terrain display accuracy won`t be degraded.
the EGPWS has its own position sensors thus the terrain display accuracy won`t be degraded.
it has no consequence on the terrain display.

variant.question:
Refer to figure 022-05.
Which mode is selected on the following Navigation Display (EHSI)?

options.text: Expanded VOR mode.
Expanded ADF mode.
Full VOR mode.
Plan mode.

variant.question: Which data will usually not be provided on the EADI while at FL190?

options.text: Radio height
Flight director crossbars
Automatic flight modes
Pitch attitude

variant.question: In accordance with (ICAO) Annex 6 part I, the flight data recorder is to be located in the aircraft :

options.text: As far to the rear as practicable
As near to the landing gear as practicable
As far forward as practicable
At the right or left wing tip

variant.question: The sensors of an INS measure:

options.text: Acceleration
Precession
The horizontal component of the earth's rotation
Velocity

variant.question:
What are the systems which provide input data into the FMS?
1. AFCS 
 2. IRS 
 3. ADC 
 4. ATS

options.text: 2 and 3.
1 and 3.
1 and 4.
2 and 4.
